subject: Re: [junit] assertEquals(Object, Object)
msgSnippet: I feel signature and documentation are not exact, it states and looks as if assertEquals should work as assertEquals for primitive types but it is not so.
messageBody:
I feel signature and documentation are not exact, it states and looks as if
assertEquals should work as assertEquals for primitive types but it is not
so. Looking at source code I understand meaning of this method (and
limitations of course). Thanks :) But I expect this meaning in Javadoc :)
public static void assertEquals(java.lang.String message,
java.lang.Object expected,
java.lang.Object actual)
Asserts that two objects are equal. If they are not an
AssertionFailedError is thrown.

----- Original Message -----
From: "Mike Clark" <mike@...>
To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Friday, May 10, 2002 9:35 PM
Subject: Re: [junit] assertEquals(Object, Object)


> Alexander Zynevich wrote:
>
> >it seems to me that these methods does not test transitivity of equals,
which is declared in Java Specification. I think documentation should state
that assertEquals(p1,p2) is completely equiv to assertTrue(p1.equals(p2))
> >am i right?
> >
>
> That's essentially correct. The assertEquals(Object o1, Object o2) does
> not directly call assertTrue(), but it does delegate to o1.equals(o2).
>
> Could you explain more about what you feel is lacking here?
>
> --
> Mike Clark
> Clarkware Consulting, Inc.
